page.title: List of multilingual countries and regions

revision.text:
{{Main article|Multilingualism|official multilingualism}} This is an incomplete list of areas with either multilingualism at the community level or at the personal level.
There is a distinction between social and personal bilingualism. Many countries, such as [[Belarus]], [[Belgium]], [[Canada]], [[India]], [[Ireland]], [[South Africa]] and [[Switzerland]], which are officially multilingual, may have many monolinguals in their population. Officially monolingual countries, on the other hand, such as [[France]], can have sizable multilingual populations. Some countries have official languages but also have regional and local official languages, notably [[Brazil]], [[China]], [[Mexico]], [[Russia]], [[Spain]] and [[Taiwan]].
==Africa==
===Central Africa===
*[[Cameroon]]: English & French (official)<ref>[http://confinder.richmond.edu/admin/docs/Cameroon.pdf Constitution of the Republic of Cameroon] Article 1</ref> + [[Cameroonian Pidgin English|Cameroonian Pidgin]]. Many ethnic and tribal languages including [[Basaa language|Basaa]], [[Duala language|Duala]], [[Manenguba language]], [[Bikya language|Bikya]], [[Bung language|Bung]], [[Fula language|Fula]], [[Kanuri language|Kanuri]], [[Ngumba language|Ngumba]], [[Yeni language|Yeni]], [[Bamum language|Bamum]], Bafia, Bakweri language and many others. Some also have fluency in the [[German language|German]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Spanish language]]s. *[[Central African Republic]]: French & [[Sango]] (official)<ref>[http://www.parliament.am/library/sahmanadrutyunner/kentronakanafrikyan.pdf Central African Republic's Constitution of 2004 with Amendments through 2010] Article 18</ref> and 50 other African languages. *[[Chad]]: Arabic & French (official)<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Chad_2005.pdf Chad's Constitution of 1996 with Amendments through 2005] Article 9</ref> + more than 100 African languages. *[[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]: French (official) + [[Lingala]], [[Kongo language|Kongo]], [[Swahili language|Swahili]] & [[Tshiluba]] (national languages)<ref>[http://www.constitutionnet.org/files/DRC%20-%20Congo%20Constitution.pdf THE CONSTITUTION OF THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO, 2005] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705042427/http://www.constitutionnet.org/files/DRC%20-%20Congo%20Constitution.pdf |date=2013-07-05 }} Article 1</ref> + 238 other languages. *[[Equatorial Guinea]]: Spanish + French + Portuguese.<ref>Fundamental Law of Equatorial Guinea, as amended in 2012 [http://www.axl.cefan.ulaval.ca/afrique/guinee_equat-lois.htm#Nouveau_texte_de_la_Constitution_de_la_Guinée_équatoriale,_ {{fr icon}}] [http://faolex.fao.org/docs/pdf/eqg128022.pdf {{es icon}}] <!-- http://www.guineaecuatorialpress.com/imgdb/2012/LEYFUNDAMENTALREFORMADA.pdf --></ref> [[Fang language|Fang]], [[Bube language|Bube]], [[Igbo language|Igbo]], [[West African Pidgin English|Pidgin English]], [[Annobonese language|Annobonese]]<ref>{{cite web |title=World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples – Equatorial Guinea: Overview |publisher=[[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|UNHCR]] |date=20 May 2008 |url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MRGI,,GNQ,,4954ce2a2,0.html |accessdate=18 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130113125024/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MRGI,,GNQ,,4954ce2a2,0.html |archivedate=13 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><!-- --><ref>{{cite book |title=Africa 2012 |first=James Tyler |last=Dickovick |publisher=Stryker Post |year=2012|isbn= 1610488822 |page=180 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NdyYjQxd7uEC&pg=PA180 |accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> *[[Republic of the Congo]]: French (official) + [[Lingala]] & [[Kituba]] [[national language]]s<ref>[http://www.presidence.cg/files/my_files/constit200102.pdf 2002 Constitution of the Republic of the Congo] Article 6{{fr icon}}</ref> + other dialects, including Kikongo and Kituba (Kikongo creole).
===East Africa===
*[[Burundi]]: [[Kirundi]] (national and official)<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Burundi_2005.pdf Burundi's Constitution of 2005] Article 5</ref> + English and French (official).<ref>[http://www.iwacu-burundi.org/blogs/english/english-is-now-official-language-of-burundi/ English is now official language of Burundi] 2014</ref> *[[Kenya]]: English (official) & Swahili (national and official)<ref>[http://www.kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Constitution_of_Kenya__2010.pdf The Constitution of Kenya, 2010] Article 7</ref> + other indigenous languages. *[[Rwanda]]: English, French, Swahili<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newtimes.co.rw/section/article/2017-02-09/207840/|title=MPs approve law making Swahili official language|last=Bishumba|first=Nasra|newspaper=The New Times Rwanda|access-date=2017-02-12|language=en}}</ref> & [[Kinyarwanda]] (co-official; Kinyarwanda - also a national one).<ref>[http://www.rwandahope.com/constitution.pdf The Constitution of the Republic of Rwanda] Article 5</ref> *[[Seychelles]]: English, French & [[Seychellois Creole]] (co-official).<ref>[http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/text.jsp?file_id=223803#LinkTarget_4263 Constitution of the Republic of Seychelles] Article 4</ref> *[[Tanzania]]: Swahili (national) + English and many other indigenous languages.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20010417124135/http://www.tanzania.go.tz/learn_kiswahili.html Kiswahili] tanzania.go.tz</ref> *[[Uganda]]: English (official), Swahili (second official)<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Uganda_2005?lang=en Constitution of the Republic of Uganda] Article 6</ref> + Arabic, [[Luganda]] + other Bantu languages & other [[Nilo-Saharan languages]].
===Horn of Africa===
*[[Djibouti]]: Arabic & French (official)<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100704104233/http://www.pogar.org/publications/other/constitutions/dj-constitution-92-e.pdf Constitution of Djibouti] Art. 1</ref> + [[Somali language|Somali]] & [[Afar language|Afar]]. *[[Eritrea]]: Tigrinya, Arabic and English are predominantly used in commerce and government affairs. The use and development of nine Eritrean languages (Tigrinya, Bilen, Afar, Saho, Rashaida, Tigre, Kunama, Nara and Hidarib) are encouraged at the local level and children attend primary school through the fifth grade in their mother tongue.<ref>[http://eritrean-embassy.se/about-eritrea/people-and-languages/ The People of Eritrea] Embassy of the State of Eritrea to the Nordic Countries</ref> *[[Ethiopia]]: the federal working languages is Amharic. On regional level, working languages are Tigrigna in Tigray<ref>[http://www.ethiopia.gov.et/tigray-regional-state Tigray Regional State]</ref>, Afarigna in Afar<ref>[http://www.ethiopia.gov.et/afar-regional-state Afar Regional State]</ref>, Oromifa (Oromigna) in Oromia<ref>[http://www.ethiopia.gov.et/oromia-regional-state Oromia Regional State]</ref>, Somali in Somali region<ref>[http://www.ethiopia.gov.et/somali-regional-state Somali Regional State]</ref>, Harari in Harari region<ref>[http://www.ethiopia.gov.et/harari-regional-state The Harari People's National Regional State]</ref> *[[Somalia]]: [[Somali language|Somali]] (official) & [[Arabic language|Arabic]] ("second language").<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130124010543/http://www.somaliweyn.com/pages/news/Aug_12/Somalia_Constitution_English_FOR_WEB.pdf Provisional Constitution of Somalia] (2012) Article 5</ref>
===North Africa===
*[[Algeria]]: Classic Arabic + [[Tamazight language|Tamazight]] (both official and national language in the constitution)<ref>[http://lughat.blogspot.com/2016/01/tamazight-official-in-algeria.html Tamazight official in Algeria]</ref><ref>[http://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/africa/DZ/algeria-constitution-with-the-amendments-of-15 Constitution of People’s Democratic Republic of Algeria. Art. 3, Art. 3 (a)]</ref> + Algerian Arabic + French and English (in media, education and business). *[[Egypt]]: Arabic (official) + [[Egyptian Arabic]], English & French. *[[Libya]]: Arabic (official) + Tamazight, [[Tamahaq languages|Tamahaq]] + Italian & English. *[[Mauritania]]: Arabic (official and national) + Poular, Soninke, and Wolof (national)<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Mauritania_2012.pdf Mauritania's Constitution of 1991 with Amendments through 2012] Article 6</ref> + French. *[[Morocco]]: Arabic + [[Berber language|Berber]] (co-official).<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Morocco_2011?lang=en Constitution of Morocco] Article 5</ref> [[Moroccan Arabic]], [[Hassaniya]] (present in the media); [[French language|French]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[English language|English]] (education and business). **[[Western Sahara]] (under Moroccan control): Hassaniya, Berber, Moroccan Arabic, Spanish and French. **[[Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic]] (in exile): Arabic (official) + Spanish (official) and French. *[[Sudan]]: Arabic & English (official [[working language]]s)<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Sudan_2005?lang=en Constitution of Sudan] Article 8</ref> + indigenous African languages. *[[South Sudan]]: Arabic & English *[[Tunisia]]: [[Modern Standard Arabic]] (official) + [[Tunisian Arabic]], [[French language|French]], [[Berber language]], [[English language|English]]
===Southern Africa===
*[[Angola]]: Portuguese (official language) + Cokwe, Kikongo, Oshiwambo, and 34 additional indigenous African languages<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/country/AO|title=Angola|work=Ethnologue}}</ref> *[[Botswana]]: English, [[Tswana language|Tswana]], Kalanga, Khoi, Herero, Afrikaans, Nama, San, Ndebele, Sign language, and 21 others.<ref>[http://www.ethnologue.com/country/BW/languages Botswana] </ref> *[[Comoros]]: Arabic, [[Comorian language|Comorian]], French (official),<ref>[http://www.constitutionnet.org/files/Comoros%20Constitution.pdf Constitution of the Federal Islamic Republic of the Comoros] Article 2</ref> Indian and Chinese languages. *[[Eswatini|Eswatini (Swaziland)]]: English + [[Swati language|Swati]].<ref>[http://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/africa/SZ/CONSTITUTION%20OF%20THE%20KINGDOM%20OF%20SWAZILAND%202005.pdf The Constitution of the Kingdom of Swaziland Act 2005] Art. 3</ref> *[[Lesotho]]: English + [[Sotho language|Sotho]].<ref>[http://library2.parliament.go.th/giventake/content_cons/lesotho.pdf Constitution of Lesotho] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303182858/http://library2.parliament.go.th/giventake/content_cons/lesotho.pdf |date=2016-03-03 }} Art. 3</ref> *[[Madagascar]]: French + [[Malagasy language|Malagasy]].<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Madagascar_2010.pdf Constitution of Madagascar] Article 4</ref> *[[Malawi]]: [[Chewa language|Chewa]] (de facto language of national identity) + English (statutory national [[working language]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/country/MW/languages|title=Malawi|work=Ethnologue}}</ref> *[[Mauritius]]: English (official, national) + French (administrative, national), [[Mauritian Creole]] (''[[lingua franca]]''), [[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Hakka language|Hakka]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Bhojpuri language|Bhojpuri]] and Arabic. *[[Mozambique]]: Portuguese (official language) + 43 additional indigenous African languages<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/country/MZ|title=Mozambique|work=Ethnologue}}</ref> *[[Namibia]]: English (official) + German, Afrikaans, [[Ovambo language|Ovambo]] (recognised regional languages)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/uil/litbase/?menu=4&programme=15|title=Effective Literacy Programmes › National Literacy Programme in Namibia|date=8 December 2009|work=unesco.org}}</ref> *[[South Africa]]: [[Afrikaans]], English, [[Southern Ndebele language|Ndebele]], [[Northern Sotho]], [[Sotho language|Sotho]], [[Tswana language|Tswana]], [[Swati language|Swati]], [[Tsonga language|Tsonga]], [[Venda language|Venda]], [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]] (co-official), sign language, Khoi, Nama and San (the languages, which the government is obliged to promote and to create conditions for their development).<ref>[http://www.gov.za/documents/constitution/chapter-1-founding-provisions Constitution of the Republic of South Africa] Article 6</ref> *[[Zimbabwe]]: Chewa, Chibarwe, English, Kalanga, Koisan, Nambya, Ndau, Ndebele, Shangani, Shona, sign language, Sotho, Tonga, Tswana, Venda and Xhosa (officially recognised).<ref>[http://www.axl.cefan.ulaval.ca/afrique/zimbabwe-cnst.htm Article 6] Constitution of Zimbabwe</ref> *[[Zambia]]: English (official) + [[Bemba language|Bemba]], [[Chewa language|Nyanja]], [[Tonga language (Zambia and Zimbabwe)|Tonga]], [[Lozi language|Lozi]], [[Lunda language|Lunda]], [[Kaonde language|Kaonde]], [[Luvale language|Luvale]], [[Ila language|Ila]], [[Mambwe-Lungu language|Mambwe]], [[Mwanga language|Namwanga]], [[Tumbuka language|Tumbuka]], [[Aushi language|Aushi]], [[Lenje language|Lenje]], [[Lala-Bisa language|Lala]] and [[Lamba language|Lamba]], and 57 others (72 in total).<ref>[http://www.zamstats.gov.zm/census.php Central Statistics Office] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121010214/http://www.zamstats.gov.zm/census.php |date=2012-01-21 }} Central Statistics Office</ref>
===West Africa===
*[[Benin]]: French (official) + many indigenous languages including [[Fon language|Fon]], [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] & [[Songhay languages|Songhay]] (specifically [[Dendi language|Dendi]]). *[[Burkina Faso]]: French (official) + [[Moore language|Moore]] and [[Jula language|Jula]] (regional languages)<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Burkina-Phrasebook-John-C-Rigdon-ebook/dp/B00PP1H5VQ Burkina Phrasebook] Book Description</ref> + indigenous Sudanic languages. *[[Cape Verde]]: Portuguese + [[Cape Verdean Creole]].<ref>Constitution of the Republic of Cabo Verde Article 9 [http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/text.jsp?file_id=181070 {{pt icon}}] [http://www.axl.cefan.ulaval.ca/afrique/Cap-Vert-const.htm {{fr icon}}]</ref> *[[Côte d'Ivoire]]: French (official) + [[Baoulé language|Baule]], [[Jula language|Jula]], and 60 other indigenous languages. *[[Gambia]]: English (official) + [[Mandinka language|Mandinka]], [[Wolof language|Wolof]], [[Fula language|Fula]] & others. *[[Ghana]]: English (official) + [[Akan language|Akan]], [[Dagaare]]/Wale, [[Dagbani language|Dagbane]], [[Adangme language|Dangme]], [[Ewe language|Ewe]], [[Ga language|Ga]], [[Gonja language|Gonja]], [[Kasem language|Kasem]] & [[Nzema language|Nzema]] + 70 others. *[[Guinea]]: French (official) +[[Maninka language|Maninka]], [[Fula language|Fula]] & [[Susu language|Susu]]. *[[Guinea-Bissau]]: Portuguese (official) + [[Guinea-Bissau Creole|Kriol]] + indigenous languages. *[[Liberia]]: English (official) + 20 African languages. *[[Mali]]: French (official) + [[Bambara language|Bambara]] (most widely spoken) + [[Fula language|Fula]] + [[Songhay languages|Songhay]] (specifically Dendi). 11 languages are used as mediums of instruction in primary schools<ref>[file:///C:/Users/User/Downloads/LOI%20REPORT%20MALI%20VARLY-final.pdf The Monitoring of Learning Outcomes in Mali] p. 1</ref> *[[Niger]]: French (official) + ten other languages recognised as national ones<ref>[http://www.axl.cefan.ulaval.ca/afrique/niger-loi-2001-037-LNG.htm Loi n° 2001-037 du 31 décembre 2001 fixant les modalités de promotion et de développement des langues nationales]{{fr icon}}</ref>, including [[Hausa language|Hausa]] (spoken by half the population) and [[Songhay languages|Songhay]] (specifically [[Zarma language|Zarma]]) *[[Nigeria]]: English (official) + [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]], [[Hausa language|Hausa]], [[Igbo language|Igbo]] as three other languages of the parliament<ref>[http://www.nigeria-law.org/ConstitutionOfTheFederalRepublicOfNigeria.htm#Procedure_Summoning_Disolution_NatAss Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria] Article 55</ref> (each of which has over 20 million speakers) + 529 other African languages (some of which have over a million speakers) + Pidgin. *[[Senegal]]: French (official) + [[Wolof language|Wolof]] (most widely spoken) + [[Fula language|Fula]] (specifically [[Pulaar]]), Diola, Malinké, Sérère, Soninké (national languages)<ref>[http://workspace.unpan.org/sites/Internet/Documents/UNPAN048952.pdf Constitution of the Republic of Senegal] Article 1</ref> + other African languages *[[Sierra Leone]]: English (official) + [[Krio language|Krio]] (most widely spoken) + [[Mende language|Mende]] + [[Temne language|Temne]] + other African languages *[[Togo]]: French (official) + [[Ewe language|Ewe]], Mina & [[Kabiyé]].
==Americas== [[File:Seattle trash lese rac basura 200511.jpg|thumb|A [[trash can]] in [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]] labeled in four languages: [[English language|English]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]] ({{linktext|垃圾}}), [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] (should be ''{{lang|vi|rác}}''), and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] also uses the Spanish word.]]
=== Caribbean === * [[Aruba]]: [[Papiamento]] and Dutch are the official languages, with Spanish and English also widely spoken. All four languages are taught in schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aruba.com/the-island/language|title=What Language Do They Speak in Aruba? Dutch & Papiamento - Aruba.com|work=aruba.com}}</ref> * [[Caribbean Netherlands]] — Dutch (overall), English (Sint Eustatius and Saba) and Papiamentu (Bonaire)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0028063/tekst_bevat_taal%2Bin%2Bhet%2Bbestuurlijk%2Bverkeer/geldigheidsdatum_14-10-2012|title=wetten.nl - Wet- en regelgeving - Invoeringswet openbare lichamen Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba - BWBR0028063|work=overheid.nl}}</ref> * [[Curaçao]] — [[Papiamento]], Dutch and English are official languages.<ref> , Spanish also widely spoken.[http://www.gobiernu.cw/web/site.nsf/web/overcura%C3%A7ao?opendocument&language=nederlands Over Curaçao] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921055639/http://www.gobiernu.cw/web/site.nsf/web/overcura%C3%A7ao?opendocument&language=nederlands|date=2013-09-21}} {{nl icon}}</ref> * [[Haiti]]: Creole and French<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Haiti_2012?lang=en Constitution of Haiti] Art. 5</ref> * [[Puerto Rico]]'s official languages<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vyQDYqz2kFsC&pg=RA1-PA62&lpg=RA1-PA62&dq=%22puerto+rico%22+official+language+1993|title=Puerto Rico: Culture, Politics, and Identity|author=Nancy Morris|publisher=Praeger/Greenwood|year=1995|isbn=0275952282|page=62|postscript=<!--None-->}} + ''Crawford J.'' [http://www.languagepolicy.net/archives/can-pr.htm Puerto Rico and Official English] 1997</ref> and languages of legislature<ref>[http://www.constitution.org/cons/puertorico-eng.htm Constitution of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico] Article III</ref> are Spanish and English, yet 85 percent of its inhabitants reported that they did not speak English "very well."{{Citation needed|date=September 2014}} * [[Trinidad and Tobago]] - in the predominantly Trinidadian English Creole-speaking country where [[Trinidadian English]] is official, Spanish was introduced as the second language of bilingual traffic signs and is spoken among 5% of the population fluently.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.co.tt/letters/0,87863.html|title=Spanish road signs quite correct|date=October 10, 2008|work=Trinidad and Tobago's Newsday}}</ref> and is generally the "first foreign language".<ref>[http://www.stte.gov.tt/Programmes/SIS/SISOverview.aspx Spanish Implementation Secretariat] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218034959/http://www.stte.gov.tt/Programmes/SIS/SISOverview.aspx|date=2015-02-18}}</ref> [[Caribbean Hindustani|Trinidadian Hindustani]] is rarely used, but spoken among [[Indo-Trinidadian and Tobagonian|Indo Trinidadian]] families, mostly the elders who preserve their ancestral language. Hindi is also used when singing songs of [[Indian subcontinent|East Indian]] origins and in the Hindu Temples. [[Antillean Creole|Trinidadian French Creole (Patois)]] is widely spoken in the communities of the northern suburbs of [[Port of Spain]] such as [[Maraval]] and [[Paramin]], where there are descendants of the early French Immigrants to Trinidad.
=== Central America === * [[Belize]]: English, Spanish and Mayan languages have some official usage{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}, although the legacy of British rule emphasised English to be most commonly used for official purposes though the majority are Hispanophone. * [[Guatemala]] has one official language which is Spanish, however, there are 23{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} distinct [[Mayan language]]s. Maya, Garifuna and Xincan languages are recognized to be essential elements of the national identity.<ref>[http://www.oj.gob.gt/es/QueEsOJ/EstructuraOJ/UnidadesAdministrativas/CentroAnalisisDocumentacionJudicial/cds/CDs%20leyes/2003/Leyes%20en%20PDF/Decretos%202003/Decreto%2019-2003.pdf Ley de idiomas nacionales] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927235237/http://www.oj.gob.gt/es/QueEsOJ/EstructuraOJ/UnidadesAdministrativas/CentroAnalisisDocumentacionJudicial/cds/CDs%20leyes/2003/Leyes%20en%20PDF/Decretos%202003/Decreto%2019-2003.pdf|date=2007-09-27}} Articulo 1-3{{es icon}} <!-- http://alertanet.org/guate-idiomas.htm --> </ref> * [[Honduras]]: Spanish is the official language, despite Afro-Caribbean English, Garifuna and indigenous languages can be found in the rural outskirts of the country. * In [[Nicaragua]], even while [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is the official language spoken broadwide (almost 95%, according to some sources{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}), there are other ''de facto'' languages such as [[English-based creole languages|Creole]], [[Miskito language|Miskitu]], [[Rama language|Rama]] and [[Mayangna language|Mayangna]] (Sumu) in their own linguistic communities. According to the Constitution, the languages of the Atlantic Coasts should be used officially in cases established by law.<ref>[https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nicaragua_2005?lang=en The Political Constitution of the Republic of Nicaragua] Article 11</ref>
=== North America === * [[Canada]] is officially bilingual under the [[Official Languages Act of Canada|Official Languages Act]] and the [[Constitution of Canada]] that require the federal government to deliver services in both official languages. As well, minority language rights are guaranteed where numbers warrant. 56.9% of the population speak English as their first language while 22.9% are native speakers of French. The remaining population belong to some of Canada's many immigrant populations or to the indigenous population. ''See [[Bilingualism in Canada]]'' **The Canadian province of British Columbia has a sizable population that speaks Mandarin or Cantonese, particularly in the city of Vancouver and its satellite town of Richmond. **The Canadian province of [[New Brunswick]], with a large [[Acadian]] population (33% French-speaking) is officially bilingual.<ref>[http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/Const/page-15.html#h-46 Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Sections 16-20] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110221331/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/const/page-15.html|date=2016-01-10}}</ref> **The [[Canadian province]] of [[Quebec]], (7.9% English-speaking){{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} Note: Quebec's largest city, Montreal, is a multilingual city with half the population having French as their mother tongue, and the other half having English or other languages as their mother tongue. <ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_demographics_of_Quebec</ref> A majority of Montrealers, whether they call themselves francophone, anglophone or allophone, know both French and English. <ref>http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2011/dp-pd/vc-rv/index.cfm?Lang=ENG&VIEW=D&GEOCODE=462&TOPIC_ID=4</ref> The city's McGill University is officially a bilingual school, allowing students to submit essays or tests in either English or French. <ref>https://www.mcgill.ca/study/2015-2016/university_regulations_and_resources/undergraduate/gi_lang_policy</ref> Although there is a sizable English-speaking population in Quebec, French is the only official language of the provincial government. At the same time, many services are provided in English, such as health services, education, legislative activities and judiciary services.<ref>[http://www.canlii.org/en/qc/laws/stat/rsq-c-c-11/latest/rsq-c-c-11.html Charter of the French Language] In some areas, government services are provided in native languages such as Inuktitut.{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623234334/http://www.canlii.org/en/qc/laws/stat/rsq-c-c-11/latest/rsq-c-c-11.html|date=2012-06-23}} Sections 7, 9, 73, 81, 87</ref> Many government services are available in English and French.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} **There are also significant French language minorities in the provinces of [[Manitoba]], [[Nova Scotia]], [[Ontario]] and [[Prince Edward Island]]. Though these provinces are not officially bilingual they do provide a number of services in French{{specify|date=February 2015}}, Ontario has a particular [[French Language Services Act]] and Manitoba — a French Language Services Policy,<ref>[https://www.gov.mb.ca/fls-slf/pdf/fls_policy.pdf French Language Services Policy]</ref> as well as a special law on recognition of seven indigenous languages<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web2.gov.mb.ca/laws/statutes/ccsm/a001-5e.php|title=The Aboriginal Languages Recognition Act|work=gov.mb.ca}}</ref> **[[Nova Scotia]] has a governmental agency for Gaelic language and culture affairs<ref>[https://beta.novascotia.ca/government/gaelic-affairs/ Gaelic Affairs] [https://gaelic.novascotia.ca Gaelic Affairs]{{ref-en}}</ref> **In [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], in the autonomous area of [[Nunatsiavut]], English and Inuttut are co-official<ref>[http://www.nunatsiavut.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/IL%202005-02%20-%20E.pdf Labrador Inuit Constitution] Part 1.6 Languages </ref> **[[Nunavut]] is a [[territories of Canada|Canadian territory]] with a population that is 85%{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} [[Inuit]]. According to Official Languages Act, its official languages are Inuit, English and French.<ref>[http://www.justice.gov.nu.ca/apps/fetch/download.aspx?file=Consolidated%20Law/Current/633640406483281250-1760189776-conssnu2008c10.pdf Official Languages Act] Art. 3</ref> **[[Northwest Territories]] have [[Chipewyan language|Chipewyan]], [[Cree language|Cree]], English, French, [[Gwich’in language|Gwich’in]], [[Inuinnaqtun language|Inuinnaqtun]], [[Inuktitut]], [[Inuvialuktun language|Inuvialuktun]], [[North Slavey language|North Slavey]], [[South Slavey language|South Slavey]] and [[Tåîchô language|Tåîchô]] as the official languages<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110809180703/http://www.nwtlanguagescommissioner.ca/pdf/Official_Languages_act.pdf Official Languages Act] Art. 4</ref> **[[Yukon]] allows the use of Yukon languages in its legislative assembly, along French and English<ref>[http://www.gov.yk.ca/legislation/acts/languages.pdf Languages Act] Art. 3-6</ref> **In many of Canada's [[First Nations]]' communities in the more isolated regions, aboriginal languages are retained. English and French are accepted in the community at the community elders' discretion.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} **In the 2006 Canadian census, information and questions are available in sixty-two languages, including eighteen [[First Nations]] languages. **The city of Toronto is one of the most multilingual cities in the world.<ref>https://elalliance.com/toronto-languages/</ref> . It is the home to over a dozen daily media outlets of different languages, including the Italian daily Corriere Canadese<ref>https://www.corriere.ca</ref> and the Chinese daily Sing Tao<ref>http://www.singtao.ca/toronto/?variant=zh-hk</ref>. *[[Mexico]]: The government recognizes 62 indigenous languages{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}, including [[Nahuatl]] spoken by more than 1.5 million people and [[Awakatek language|Aguacatec]] spoken by 27 people, along with Spanish. Lately also have much influence is the English by the number of tourists and American and British residents. *In [[Suriname]], Dutch, [[Sranan Tongo|Sranan]], and English are spoken by almost everyone.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} In addition, Chinese and various Indian languages are spoken. * [[Uruguay]] has a large [[Italian Uruguayan|Italian-speaking minority]] also proficient in Spanish.
