{{Infobox video game | image = | alt = | caption = | developer = IJsfontein Interactive Media | publisher = Bombilla (Dutch)
Van In (Belgium)
VNU Interactive
Tivola (English & German)
Gallimard (French) | series = | engine = | platforms = MacOS, Windows | released = November 1997 | genre = Adventure | modes = }} '''''Masters of the Elements''''' is an educational adventure video game developed by IJsfontein Interactive Media, and published by Bombilla (Dutch), Van In (Belgium), VNU Interactive, Tivola (English & German), and Gallimard (French).{{cite web|url=http://retro.nrc.nl/W2/Nieuws/1999/10/08/Med/03.html|title=Nieuwsselectie: Media|website=retro.nrc.nl}} The game was originally released in November, 1997 and ended up on Macintosh and Windows. In the Anglosphere, it was published by Tivola, who had recently published other edutainment titles such as [[Physicus]], [[Bioscopia]], and [[Chemicus]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.gameboomers.com/reviews/Mm/MastersElementsbyjenny100.htm|title=Masters of the Elements review|last=jenny100|website=www.gameboomers.com|access-date=2018-03-31}} Originally in Dutch, the game was later translated into English, German, Japanese, French and Italian. The game was voiced by Joost Prinsen and won a BAFTA Award in 1999 after its English-language release. ==Production== The game was created by Jan Willem Huisman, Hayo Wagenaar, and Sander Hassing.{{cite web|url=https://www.volkskrant.nl/wetenschap/het-handige-sprookje-van-drie-snotneuzen~a452355/|title=Het handige sprookje van drie snotneuzen - Wetenschap - Voor nieuws, achtergronden en columns|website=De Volkskrant}} The three developers at IJsfontein knew each other from the InterAction Design department of the Utrecht School of the Arts, where they designed the concept of the game. Hajo Wagenaar made all the drawings, Sander Hassing served as programmer, Jan Willem Huisman organised the operation.{{cite web|url=https://www.trouw.nl/cultuur/een-spannend-spel-met-een-literaire-bodem-voor-de-pc~acb843c7/|title=Een spannend spel met een literaire bodem voor de pc|website=Trouw}} The came up with the name "IJsfontein" during the development of this game, which was their first project; while other development companies had English names they wanted to choose something Dutch-sounding.http://www.publicspacemedia.nl/downloads/158_159_inAM2_NAMENLR.pdf The game's sound designer came up with "Ice fountain" because ice is static while a fountain is dynamic. While getting into large debt, the team was invited to the Cannes expo named Milia, where they set up a stall in a section for young talent. Interest from a Japanese publisher put them in a strong negotiating position with VNU Interactive; while it was standard for the publisher to get rights to the game, the develoeprs refused. They felt the publisher was condescending from their comments that the world does not work the way they think it does. Upon signing a contract with the Chinese, they discovered VNU still expected the company to lose the copyright due to not meeting a deadline. The team entered into a 'double or nothing' negotiation, whereby failing to complete the titled by 6 October, it would result in heavy royalty regulations. The team ultimately presented a beta version to children at an Amsterdam primary school, after suffering through a panic-stricken September. The game was playtested by children from the top three groups of primary school; the developers noted the potential for the game to be popular with girld due to them finding solutions in a process-wise way, as opposed to boys who will click the screen 10,000 times until something happens. By 2016, 40 people would work at IJsfontein.{{cite web|url=http://kindermediaawards.nl/uitreiking-7-april/|title=- Kinder Media Awards|publisher=}} ===Design=== It was one of the first [[serious game]]s ever to be developed.{{cite web|url=https://www.ijsfontein.nl/en/projecten/masters-of-power|title=Masters of Power – award-winning debuut - By IJsfontein|publisher=}} At the time, IJsfontein was the first Dutch studio to explicitly develop a game with an educational bend.http://creativeindustries.com.cuhk.edu.hk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/European-Game-Industry-Report-2013.pdf The game attempts to bridge two opposing sides of the video gaming market by offering an experience that is both fun and educational.{{cite web|url=http://retro.nrc.nl/W2/Nieuws/1997/12/19/Med/09.html|title=Nieuwsselectie: Media|website=retro.nrc.nl}} == Plot and gameplay == In the Castle of Infinity, there are five masters that bring balance to the elements. When Master of Chance loses his cat, the balance of the elements is disturbed. It is up to the player to collect pages of the Garden of Chance story, which will then cause Master of Chance to reveal clues about the whereabouts of his cat. The game is puzzle based, with themes ranging from the natural world to physics to science.{{cite web|url=https://www.sprout.nl/artikel/special-marketing-20-game-marketing|title=Special marketing 2.0: Game marketing|publisher=}} == Critical reception == Gameboomers felt the puzzles required more dexterity than thought. Feibel felt the game was difficult and beautifully illustrated.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126062205/http://www.feibel.de/index.php?id=7&catId=11&prodId=2129&cHash=62b01939735c814423e155b9992d4154|title=Alle Spiele - Meister Zufall und die Herrscher der Elemente - Experimente, Rätsel und Geheimnisse|date=26 November 2015|publisher=}} The essay ''Op de koffie bij de Meester van Wanhoop '' thought the game demonstrated the wondrous potential of merging art and play in the digital world.{{cite web|url=http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_lit004199901_01/_lit004199901_01_0043.php|title=Literatuur zonder leeftijd. Jaargang 13 · dbnl|first=|last=DBNL|website=DBNL}} The game won a BAFTA award and a La Fletche d'Or. The game was nominated for the Bafta for most instructive game for children, and for the most interactive game for children. The game was featured at the IFFR.{{cite web|url=https://iffr.com/nl/1998/films/meesters-van-macht|title=Meesters van Macht|date=4 September 2015|publisher=}} The game was also a commercial successhttps://books.google.com.au/books?id=xQgbDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=IJsfontein+"Meister+Zufall+und+die+Herrscher+der+Elemente"+OR+"Meesters+van+Macht"+OR+"Le+Maître+des+éléments"&source=bl&ots=08jw0cxe7b&sig=jGcEdGmxyzBlV8SkdtGZsnGuAZs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLttafyZXaAhWIGJQKHRNCC8gQ6AEIeDAO#v=onepage&q=IJsfontein%20"Meister%20Zufall%20und%20die%20Herrscher%20der%20Elemente"%20OR%20"Meesters%20van%20Macht"%20OR%20"Le%20Maître%20des%20éléments"&f=false, and become one of the best-selling pieces of Dutch CD-ROM software. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.ijsfontein.nl/en/projecten/masters-of-power Main page] [[Category:1997 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Educational video games]] [[Category:Mac OS games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Windows games]]

The '''Neues Wiener Konservatorium''' ('''New Vienna Conservatory''') was a [[music school]] established in [[Vienna]] by [[Theobald Kretschmann]] in 1909. In 1929 it had the largest number of enrolled students during its lifetime.
Other names include ''Privatmusikschule Theobald Kretschmann'' and ''Neues Konservatorium für Musik''.
Among its faculty were [[Richard Robert]] (briefly its director), [[Simon Pullman]] and Severin Eisenberger.

{{BLP sources|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western philosophy]] |era = [[20th-century philosophy]] |image = Nicholas Wolterstorff.jpg |name = Nicholas Wolterstorff |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1932|1|21|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Bigelow, Minnesota|Bigelow]], [[Minnesota]] |death_date = |school_tradition = [[Analytic philosophy|Analytic]] |main_interests = [[Epistemology]], [[metaphysics]], [[philosophy of religion]], [[aesthetics]], [[political philosophy]] |notable_ideas = [[Reformed epistemology]] |influences = [[Alvin Plantinga]]{{·}} [[Thomas Reid]]{{·}} [[Abraham Kuyper]]{{·}} [[Augustine]]{{·}} [[John Calvin]] |influenced = [[Kendall Walton]] |academic_advisors = [[Donald Cary Williams]]<ref>{{Cite journal|title=A Life in Philosophy|first=Nicholas|last=Wolterstorff|journal=Proceedings and Addresses of the American Philosophical Association|volume=81|number=2| date=November 2007 |jstor=27653995}}</ref> }}
'''Nicholas Wolterstorff''' (born January 21, 1932) is an [[American philosopher]]. A prolific writer with wide-ranging philosophical and theological interests, he has written books on [[aesthetics]], [[epistemology]], [[political philosophy]], [[philosophy of religion]], [[metaphysics]], and [[philosophy of education]]. In ''Faith and Rationality,'' Wolterstorff, [[Alvin Plantinga]], and [[William Alston]] developed and expanded upon a view of [[religious epistemology]] that has come to be known as [[Reformed epistemology]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/sum2017/entries/religion-epistemology/|title=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|last=Forrest|first=Peter|date=2017|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Summer 2017}}</ref>. He also helped to establish the journal ''[[Faith and Philosophy]]'' and the [[Society of Christian Philosophers]]. [[File:WolterstoffLecture(AMJ).jpg|thumb|Wolterstorff speaking in a conference in South Korea, May 24, 2014]] ==Education and academic career== ===Degrees=== * [[Calvin College]], [[Grand Rapids]], [[Michigan]] [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in philosophy 1953 * [[Harvard University]], [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] and [[PhD]] in philosophy 1956 * [[Vrije Universiteit]], Honorary Doctorate in philosophy 2007<ref name="test">{{Citation | publisher = VU | place = NL | work = Top researchers | title = Honorary doctorates | URL = http://vu.nl/en/research/topresearchers-at-vu/honorary-doctorates/index.asp}}.</ref>.
===University positions=== * Professor of Philosophy, [[Calvin College]] (1959–1989) * [[Noah Porter]] [[Professor]] of Philosophical [[Theology]], [[Yale University]] (1989–2001) and, concurrently, Adjunct Professor in the Philosophy Department and the Religious Studies Department
===Visiting professorships=== * [[Harvard University]], [[Princeton University]], Yale University, [[Oxford University]], [[University of Notre Dame]], [[University of Texas]], [[University of Michigan]], [[Temple University]], the Free University of Amsterdam ([[Vrije Universiteit]]), and the [[University of Virginia]].
==Professional distinctions== * Woodrow Wilson Fellowship, 1953 * Harvard Foundation Fellowship, 1954 * Josiah Royce Memorial Fellowship, Harvard University, 1954 * Fulbright Scholarship, 1957 * President of the American Philosophical Association (Central Division) * President of the Society of Christian Philosophers * Senior Fellow, Institute for Advanced Study in Culture, [[University of Virginia]], 2005
==Endowed lectureships== * Kuyper Lectures, Free University of Amsterdam, 1981 * [[Wilde Lectures]], [[Oxford University]], 1993 * [[Gifford Lectures]], [[St Andrews University]], 1995 * Tate-Willson Lectures, [[Southern Methodist University]], 1991 *[[Stone Lectures]], [[Princeton Theological Seminary]], 1998 * [http://digital.library.sbts.edu/handle/10392/535 Lectures at Southern Seminary], [http://digital.library.sbts.edu/handle/10392/536 Lecture #2], [http://digital.library.sbts.edu/handle/10392/537 Lecture #3], [[Southern Baptist Theological Seminary|The Southern Baptist Theological Seminary]], 2000 * [[Taylor Lectures]], Yale University, 2001 * Laing Lectures, [[Regent College]], 2007
==Personal life== Nicholas Wolterstorff lives in Grand Rapids, Michigan with his wife Claire. He has 4 grown children and 1 that died at age 25 while mountain climbing in Austria. He has seven grandchildren.
==Thought== While an undergraduate at Calvin College, Wolterstorff was greatly influenced by professors [[William Harry Jellema]], [[Henry Stob]] and [[Henry Zylstra]], who introduced him to schools of thought that have dominated his mature thinking: Reformed theology and [[Scottish Common Sense Realism|common sense]] philosophy (these have also influenced the thinking of Wolterstorff's friend and colleague [[Alvin Plantinga]], another alumnus of Calvin College).
Wolterstorff builds upon the ideas of the Scottish common sense philosopher [[Thomas Reid]], who approached knowledge "from the bottom-up". Instead of reasoning about [[transcendence (philosophy)|transcendental]] conditions of knowledge, Wolterstorff suggests that knowledge and our knowing faculties are not the subject of our research but have to be seen as its starting point. Wolterstorff rejects classical [[foundationalism]] and instead sees knowledge as based upon insights in reality which are direct and indubitable.

Ashworth | awards = Innovation Award at the Las Vegas [[Consumer Electronics Show]] | website = [https://nicolas-babin.blogspot.fr/ Personal website] }} '''Nicolas Babin''' (born April 9, 1966) is a [[France|French]] businessman, specialized in [[gamification]], as well as technological innovation. He is best known for being the former [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Sony]] Europe in several departments, including robotics.{{cite web|title=Sony Entertainment robot AIBO makes debut in European retail|url=http://www.protext.cz/zprava.php?id=4159|location=[[Berlin]]|website=Protext, distribution of press releases in the Czech Republic|language=English|date=5 August 2002|access-date=26 January 2018}} He is currently at the head of Babin Business Consulting. == Early life and career == Nicolas Babin studied at the École supérieure des ingénieurs commerciaux de Bordeaux in computer science.{{cite web|title=Nicolas Babin est nommé directeur général de Concoursmania|url=https://www.lesechos.fr/19/10/2010/LesEchos/20787-053-ECH_nicolas-babin.htm|website=[[Les Échos (newspaper)|Les Échos]]|language=fr|date=19 October 2010|access-date=26 January 2018}} He is the holder of a master in Sales-Marketing.{{cite web|title=Nicolas Babin est promu marketing director, global director digital solutions de Neopost.|url=http://www.e-marketing.fr/Thematique/management-1090/Nominations/nicolas-Babin-est-promu-marketing-director-global-director-digital-solutions-neopost-248000.htm#gCO6p1f9Irmk2jsD.97|website=E-marketing|language=fr|date=25 November 2014|access-date=25 January 2018}} He began his career in 1989 for [[BNP Paribas]] as a programmer in [[San Francisco]]. He moved to California as a result. In 1992, he left BNP Paribas in order to take the head of the French and German branches for Atwork Health Systems. He then left Atwork in order to take the head of Administration for Cats Software US, thus moving to [[Palo Alto]], in [[California]]. He notably contributed to its [[Initial public offering|IPO]],{{cite web|title=Nicolas Babin|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=132904364&privcapId=223684118&previousCapId=223684118&previousTitle=Fjord%20Technologies%20S.A.S|website=[[Bloomberg News]]|language=English|access-date=26 January 2018}} before becoming the Managing Director EMEA for Cats Software in [[London]]. == Career == === The Sony Years (1997-2008) === Nicolas Babin began his career for Sony in 1997, where he became the Managing Director for [[Sony]] Europe for [[Etak]] a unit of the Sony group specialized in [[digital mapping]] in London. In 2001, while living in [[Brussels]] and being the Managing Director for Sony Entertainment Robot Europe,{{cite web|title=Sony’s AIBO Gains New Colours and New Tricks|url=http://www.trustedreviews.com/news/sonys-aibo-gains-new-colours-and-new-tricks-2732044|website=Trusted Reviews|language=English|date=5 February 2011|access-date=26 January 2018}} he contributed to the launch of [[AIBO]], Sony's robotic pets{{cite web|title=Sony Aibo: Clever doggy|url=http://metro.co.uk/2003/10/22/sony-aibo-clever-doggy-381387/|website=[[Metronews]]|language=English|date=22 October 2003|access-date=26 January 2018}}{{,}}{{cite web|title=Sony's AIBO entertainment robot gets its skates on|url=http://services.sony.co.uk/support/aibo/downloads/en/Speed_Board_pr.pdf|location=[[London|Londres]]|website=Communiqué de presse de Sony|language=English|date=22 October 2002|access-date=26 January 2018}}{{,}}.{{cite web|title=LES CHERCHEURS N'EN FINISSENT PAS DE FAIRE LE CLONE|url=http://www.strategies.fr/etudes-tendances/dossiers/r33475W/les-chercheurs-n-en-finissent-pas-de-faire-le-clone.html|website=Stratégies|language=fr|date=10 June 2004|access-date=26 January 2018}} In 2004 he became the Director of Corporate Communications Sony Europe in [[Berlin]] and contributed to the marketing of the most recent Sony products{{cite web|title=Nicolas Babin, directeur général du groupe ConcoursMania|url=http://www.strategies.fr/guides-annuaires/nominations/147447W/nicolas-babin-directeur-general-du-groupe-concours-mania.html|website=Stratégies|date=22 October 2010|access-date=25 January 2015}}{{,}}.{{cite web|title=HP and Sony battle for domination of digital entertainment|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/07/20/hp_sony_battle_for_digital_home|website=[[The Register]]|language=English|date=20 July 2005|access-date=26 January 2018}} In 2005, he also contributed to the launch of the [[PlayStation Portable|PSP]] in Europe.{{cite web|title=Sony chief in Europe aims to restore brand's glitter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/14/technology/sony-chief-in-europe-aims-to-restore-brands-glitter.html|website=[[New York Times]]|language=English|date=14 April 2005|access-date=29 January 2018}} In 2006, during the battery recall controversy that Sony faced (some [[Personal computer|notebook computers]] from brands like [[Toshiba]], [[Dell]], [[Lenovo]] or [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] were provided with built-in lithium batteries that could provoke fire due to overheating, causing property damage or minor burns, forcing Sony to initiate the biggest recall recall policy in the world at the time),{{cite web|title=Sony Apologizes for Battery Recall|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/24/AR2006102400278.html|website=[[Washington Post]]|language=English|date=24 October 2006|access-date=26 January 2018}}{{cite web|title=Batteries Sony, un rappel massivement multi-marques|url=http://www.liberation.fr/futurs/2006/09/29/batteries-sony-un-rappel-massivement-multi-marques_5164|website=[[Libération]]|language=fr|date=29 September 2006|access-date=26 January 2018}} Nicolas Babin was heavily involved in the crisis management.{{cite book|language=English|author1=Michael D. Watkins|author2=Clayton M. Christensen|author3=Kenneth L. Kraemer|author4=Michael E. Porter|title=Harvard Business Review Leadership Library: The Executive Collection|pages=72|lieu=|editor=Harvard Business Review Press|date=October 13, 2015|isbn=|url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=jvKECgAAQBAJ&pg=RA8-PA72&dq=nicolas+babin+sony+battery&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ67Hq3vbYAhVDbxQKHSJSACoQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=nicolas%20babin&f=false}} === Technological innovations (2008-2017) === Nicolas Babin left Sony in 2008 in order to join [[AT Internet]], a French company specialized in web analytics, becoming the company Chief Operating Officer. He occupied this post during the Google bug in 2009, or when Microsoft allowed other [[Web browser|browsers]] on their machines{{cite web|title="Samedi, les visites générées par Google ont chuté de 90 %"|url=http://www.journaldunet.com/ebusiness/le-net/interview/samedi-les-visites-generees-par-google-ont-chute-de-90.shtml|website=Le Journal du Net|date=2 February 2009|access-date=26 January 2018}}{{,}}.{{cite web|title=Europe Drops Microsoft Antitrust Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/17/business/global/17msft.html|website=[[New York Times]]|language=English|date=16 December 2009|access-date=29 January 2018}} In 2010, he became the Managing Director of the Groupe Concoursmania in France, specialized in online competition and marketing gaming. He notably managed the IPO process of the Groupe Concoursmania, as well as its developpement in Europe.{{cite web|title=Groupe Concoursmania names Nicolas Babin as managing director|url=http://en.actiplay.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/PR_Groupe-ConcoursMania-Nicolas-Babin-DG_12102010.pdf|website=Groupe ConcoursMania Press Release|language=English|date=12 October 2010|access-date=26 January 2018}} He then joined [[Neopost]] in 2013, a French company specialized in [[franking machines]] or [[postage meters]] as the marketing Director and as the head of the group of Digital Solutions.{{cite web|title=Le top 20 des influenceurs E-commerce|url=https://www.ecommerce-nation.fr/top-20-influenceurs-ecommerce/|website=E Commerce Nation|date=29 June 2017|access-date=26 January 2018}} He then left Neopost in 2017. Nicolas Babin is also a board member of several companies, including Commanders Act,{{cite web|title=About Us|url=https://www.commandersact.com/en/company/about-us/|website=Commanders Act|language=English|access-date=25 January 2018}} Maxicoffee{{cite web|title=Company profiles : Maxicoffee|url=https://pitchbook.com/profiles/company/64258-30|website=Pitchbook|language=English|access-date=25 January 2018}} or GamFed,{{cite web|title=GamFed Overview|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/gamfed|website=Crunchbase|language=English|access-date=25 January 2018}} a company he founded in 2012 in order to developp [[gamification]].{{cite web|title=Naissance de GamFed|url=http://www.actiplay.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/CP_Gamfed_12122012.pdf|location=[[Bordeaux]]|website=Communiqué de presse|date=12 December 2012|access-date=25 January 2018}} === Consulting (2017-...) === In March 2017, Nicolas Babin founded his own company Babin Business Consulting,{{cite web|title=Dirigeants : Nicolas Babin|url=https://dirigeants.bfmtv.com/Nicolas-BABIN-6513319/|website=[[BFM TV]]|language=fr|access-date=26 January 2017}} specialized in consulting, marketing, innovations and business development, which he presides since then{{cite web|title=From Claude Posternak to Fleur Pellerin, These Are the Most Influential Entrepreneurs From France|url=https://richtopia.com/inspirational-people/top-100-most-influential-french-entrepreneurs|website=Richtopia|language=en|access-date=2 September 2018}}. Nicolas Babin is also the cofounder of Mirambeau AppCare, which product includes DiabiLive{{cite web|title=Mirambeau App Care|url=https://www.so-start-up.fr/les-entreprises/mirambeauappcare/|website=So Start Up|access-date=29 January 2018}}{{,}},{{cite web|title=Mirambeau AppCare appuyé par la Région et The '''Open Source University Meet-Up''' is a student developer organization sponsored by [[Sun Microsystems]] that educates its members about [[Open source software|open-source]] technologies through technical demonstrations, access to web courses, and discounts on Sun Certification.<ref name=sunosum>[http://developers.sun.com/students/osum/index.jsp Open Source University Meet-Up (OSUM)]</ref>
==History== Sun started the Open Source University Meet-Up as part of its program to help connect students in computer science to its technologies. Typically led by a campus ambassador or on-campus volunteer, Open Source University Meet-Ups exist in many countries.<ref name=sunmap>[http://developers.sun.com/students/osum/index.jsp Campus Ambassadors Map]</ref>
==Purpose== The Open Source University Meet-Up is a place for Sun to connect student developers to Sun’s wide array of open source software platforms, following Sun’s initiatives to open-source all of its software technologies. As a whole it also helps give software developers, students, and other interested people an opportunity to learn more about open source software.<ref name=iowaosum>[http://www.iowaosum.com/about About OSUM]</ref>
==See also== [[MSDN Academic Alliance]]

'''Pre-medical''' (often referred to as '''pre-med''') is an educational track that [[undergraduate]] students in the United States and Canada pursue prior to becoming medical students. It involves activities that prepare a student for [[medical school]], such as pre-med coursework, volunteer activities, clinical experience, research, and the application process. Some pre-med programs providing broad preparation are referred to as “pre-professional” and may simultaneously prepare students for entry into a variety of [[first professional degree]] or [[graduate school]] programs that require similar prerequisites (such as medical, veterinary, or pharmacy schools). ==Major== At most colleges and universities, students do not have the option of pre-medical [[academic major]] or [[Minor (academic)|minor]]. A student on a pre-med track may choose any undergraduate major in any field, so long as certain required courses are completed. Such courses are generally focused in the scientific fields of [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[organic chemistry]], [[neuroscience]], and [[physics]], which are necessary to prepare for the [[Medical College Admission Test]] (MCAT)<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.aamc.org/students/applying/mcat/preparing/ | title=Preparing for the MCAT Exam | publisher=AMCAS | accessdate=November 17, 2011}}</ref> and satisfy most medical school prerequisites.<ref name=AAMCReq /> It is for this reason students on a pre-med track generally undertake a major associated with one of those fields; however, an increasing number of students with a background in humanities have been applying in recent years,<ref name="AAMC2010MajorData">{{cite web | url=https://www.aamc.org/download/161692/data/table18-facts2010mcatgpabymaj1-web.pdf.pdf | title=MCAT and GPAs for Applicants and Matriculants to U.S. Medical Schools by Primary Undergraduate Major, 2010 | publisher=AAMC | accessdate=November 17, 2011}}</ref> a situation applauded by medical schools.<ref name="newsweek">{{Citation | last=Kliff | first=Sarah | url=http://saveksuhistory.wordpress.com/2007/09/06/newsweek-med-schools-seek-more-nonscience-students/ | title=Med Schools Seek More Nonscience Students | newspaper=[[Newsweek]] | date=10 September 2007}}</ref> For example, [[Mount Sinai School of Medicine]] has created a program specifically for non-science majors. The Humanities and Medicine Program admits undergraduates majoring in the humanities or social sciences without requiring the MCAT, or science coursework.<ref name="nytimes">{{Citation | last=Hartocollis | first=Anemona | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/30/nyregion/30medschools.html | title=Getting Into Medical School Without Hard Sciences | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=10 July 2010}}</ref>
==Pre-med timeline== Typical pre-med students will structure their coursework in their first year in [[university]] to accommodate the required courses. After a semester, many pursue extracurricular activities that demonstrate a commitment to medicine. Once junior year arrives, students register for and take the MCAT, the required standardized exam that medical schools use to identify qualified candidates.<ref name="newsweek"/> Once the test is taken, students apply to various schools using the automated [[American Medical College Application Service]] (AMCAS) system, [[American Association of Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine Application Service]] (AACOMAS) system, or in some cases, the school's own application system. AMCAS primary applications are verified by AMCAS staff, a process that often takes four to six weeks.<ref name="newsweek"/> The application process consists of a review of academic records, MCAT scores, activities, work experience, and a personal statement.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://hms.harvard.edu/admissions/default.asp?page=selection | title=Selection Factors | publisher=Harvard Medical School | accessdate=November 17, 2011}}</ref> Applicants can expect to hear from schools within a few months, at which point they may receive "secondary applications".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://prehealthadvising.com/2010/11/2011-2012-medical-school-application-timeline/ | title=2011-2012 Medical School Application Timeline | publisher=prehealthadvising.com | accessdate=November 17, 2011}}</ref> Different schools have different policies on sending secondary applications to students; many send secondary applications to all students, others screen applications prior to inviting an applicant to submit a secondary application. These applications are generated by each individual school. They generally contain essay questions that the applicant must answer to demonstrate that the applicant possesses qualities that the schools deem necessary to be a good medical student and physician.<ref name=PRMSA>{{cite web | url=http://www.princetonreview.com/medical/medical-school-applications.aspx | title=Medical School Applications | publisher=The Princeton Review | accessdate=November 17, 2011}}</ref> Qualified applicants can next expect to receive invitations to interview at schools. Upon completion of an interview and receipt of any additional application materials, the application is considered to be complete, and the student then waits for the school's decision to either accept or reject the student.<ref name=PRMSA />
Some applicants receive admittance to medical school through a "post-baccalaureate" pre-medical program. These programs may be formal, such as the programs offered through [[Columbia University |Columbia]], [[Johns Hopkins University |Johns Hopkins]], [[Mayo Clinic]] with Barrett, The Honors College, [[Bryn Mawr College |Bryn Mawr]], [[Goucher]] and [[Scripps College |Scripps]], or semi-formal, such as the program offered at [[Harvard University |Harvard]], but often consist of a student informally enrolling in a college to complete science coursework required for admission to medical school prior to sitting for the MCAT. The [[Association of American Medical Colleges]] (AAMC) maintains a list of all formal and semi-formal post-baccalaureate pre-medical programs in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://services.aamc.org/postbac/ | title=Postbaccalaureate Premedical Programs - Search | publisher=AAMC | accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref>
==Coursework== The AAMC has created a list of required courses that every pre-med student must take.<ref name=AAMCReq /> Each school is allowed to place its own further requirements.
The pre-medical coursework is offered at many American colleges and [[universities]]; however, it is considered to be a "track" that follows a certain curriculum. Most pre-medical students major in the natural and applied sciences, such as [[agricultural science]], biology, chemistry, or physics, though this is not a requirement. Some pre-professional degree programs in agriculture prepare students for direct entry into the workforce in fields in high demand, while also meeting requirements for medical or veterinary schools.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cals.cornell.edu/admissions/academics/pre-professional-programs/ |title=Pre-professional Programs | College of Agriculture and Life Sciences |publisher=[[Cornell University College of Agriculture and Life Sciences]] |accessdate=2014-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://eppws.nmsu.edu/pre-professional-program/ |title=Pre-professional Programs NMSU |publisher= New Mexico State University}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://ag.purdue.edu/foodsci/Pages/premed.aspx |title=Pre-Med |publisher=[[Purdue University]] |accessdate=2014-04-08}}</ref> The latter curriculum model is meant to enhance employability of graduates awaiting admission or choosing not to attend professional or graduate school.
The courses that must be taken to meet the pre-medical requirements from the AAMC are two years of chemistry, with one being in chemistry, one year of biology, and one year of physics.<ref name=AAMCReq>{{cite web | url=https://www.aamc.org/students/applying/requirements/ | title=Admission Requirements | publisher=AAMC | accessdate=November 17, 2011}}</ref> These course requirements are expected to change since the MR5 Committee, charged with revising the MCAT has created a new set of core competencies for success in medical education and practice. Those core competencies will include a greater emphasis on molecular genetics within the biology curriculum and will include biochemistry. In addition, the 2015 MCAT will test in areas related to multicultural sensitivity and in critical analysis of ethics and philosophy.<ref name=newAAMCReq>{{cite web | url=https://www.aamc.org/students/download/266006/data/2015previewguide.pdf | title=2015 MCAT preview | publisher=AAMC | accessdate=March 24, 2012}}</ref><ref name="New York Times">{{cite news |last=Rosenthal |first=Elizabeth | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/15/education/edlife/pre-meds-new-priorities-heart-and-soul-and-social-science.html?_r=4&ref=elisabethrosenthal& | title= Pre-Med’s New Priorities: Heart and Soul and Social Science | accessdate=April 24, 2012}}</ref> Many colleges of medicine and undergraduate pre-medical advising offices have yet to formalize pre-medical curricular recommendations. Though it did not address changes in the mathematics, physics, psychosocial or humanities portion of pre-medical education, the [[American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology]] (ASBMB) developed a set of pre-medical curricular recommendations. ASBMB advocated that the year of biology includes genetics; that general and organic chemistry be taught with an orientation toward the chemistry of molecules encountered in living things; that one semester of biochemistry be required and two semesters of biochemistry be recommended; and that the laboratory course requirement can be taught in biology, chemistry or biochemistry, so long as research methods and data analysis are emphasized.<ref name=ASBMBcurriculum>{{cite web | url=http://www.asbmb.org/asbmbtoday/asbmbtoday_article.aspx?id=16052 | title=ASBMB pre-medical curriculum | publisher=ASBMB | accessdate=March 24, 2012}}</ref>
Pre-medical students may be advised or required to take upper level biology and chemistry electives, such as [[cellular biology]], [[physical chemistry]], [[biochemistry]], [[molecular biology]] and [[genetics]]. Specific requirements for these courses vary by institution. Schools may also have requirements for non-science classes. Some require a certain number of general [[humanities]] credits, while others have specific requirements for courses in [[English studies |English]], [[psychology]], or other disciplines.
==Volunteering and clinical experiences== Many pre-medical students volunteer in a health care setting to explore the option of a career in medicine. Past volunteer experience can increase an applicant's chances of acceptance to a medical school.<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith-Barrow |first=Delece |title=Bolster a Medical School Application With Volunteer Work |url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-graduate-schools/top-medical-schools/articles/2013/09/04/bolster-a-medical-school-application-with-volunteer-work |publisher=US News & World Report}}</ref> Often volunteer experiences are topics of discussion during medical school interviews.<ref>{{cite web |last=Franco |first=Kathleen |title=How Volunteer Work Can Offer Lessons to Prospective Medical Students |url=https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/medical-school-admissions-doctor/2014/04/22/how-volunteer-work-can-offer-lessons-to-prospective-medical-students |publisher=US News & World Report |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref> Some students "shadow" a physician, where the student follows a physician, directly observing the doctor as they care for patients.<ref>{{cite web |last=Chang |first=Edward |title=Shadow a Physician to Gain Insight for Medical School |url=https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/medical-school-admissions-doctor/2014/01/28/shadow-a-physician-to-gain-insight-for-medical-school |publisher=US News & World Report}}</ref>
==Other countries== In Australia and the United Kingdom, a number of universities offer a three or four year Bachelor of Medical Science, Bachelor of Health Sciences or Biomedical Science degree, which is similar in content and aim to pre-med courses in the US. However, it is also possible to gain entry to a professional degree program in medicine (usually the Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery degree) directly from High School if the applicant achieves high grades upon graduation and is successful in the [[Undergraduate Medicine and Health Sciences Admission Test]] (UMAT), for Australian and New Zealand medicine courses, and the [[UK Clinical Aptitude Test]] (UKCAT) and [[BioMedical Admissions Test]] (BMAT) for UK medicine courses.

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox hospital <!-- Full documentation: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Infobox_hospital --> | name = Pyongyang Maternity Hospital | org/group = <!-- org or group that owns/manages the hospital --> | logo = <!-- please conform to copyright --> | logo_size = <!-- logo size or width in pixels --> | image = File:North Korea-Pyongyang Maternity Hospital-01.jpg | image_size = 225 <!-- image size or width in pixels (225 matches default map_size) --> | alt = Entrance of the Pyongyang Maternity Hospital pictured in Summer 2008 | caption = Entrance of the Pyongyang Maternity Hospital | map_type = Pyongyang <!-- uses the [[Template:Location map]] format; defines value for {{{1}}} parameter; must have latitude and longitude if using this --> | relief = <!-- any non-blank value (yes, 1, etc.) will cause the template to display a relief map image, where available --> | map_size = 225 | map_alt = <!-- alternative text for map image, see WP:ALT for details --> | map_caption = Location in Pyongyang | coordinates = {{coord|39|1|28|N|125|46|50|E|type:landmark_region:KP-01|display=inline,title}} | location = <!-- optional - displayed before region, state, country --> | region = [[Pyongyang]] | state = | country = [[North Korea]] | healthcare = Public | funding = Public | type = Specialist | affiliation = <!-- medical school / university affiliations (medical or paramedical) --> | patron = <!-- the individual who acts as the hospital patron --> | helipad = Yes<ref name="Becker2005">{{cite book|author=Jasper Becker|title=Rogue Regime : Kim Jong Il and the Looming Threat of North Korea: Kim Jong Il and the Looming Threat of North Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UpZWfYqiVLMC&pg=PA141|date=1 May 2005|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-803810-8|page=141}}</ref> | beds = 1500, of which 1000 are for adults and 500 are for children<ref name="WHO_2005"/> | speciality = [[Maternity hospital]], [[medical education]] | founded = Building finished in 1979.<ref name="Lim2008"/> Started operating on 30 July 1980.<ref name="Corfield2014"/> | website = <!-- use {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | other_links = <!-- link(s) to related articles --> }} {{Infobox Korean name | hangul =평양산원 | hanja = | rr =Pyeongyang Sanwon | mr =P'yŏngyang Sanwon | koreanipa = | context =north | image = | caption = | text = <!--| child =yes}}--> }} '''Pyongyang Maternity Hospital''' ({{korean|context=north|hangul = 평양산원}}) is a [[maternity hospital|maternity]] and [[teaching hospital]] in [[Pyongyang]]. Nurses and [[midwives]] are educated in the hospital for work outside the North Korean capital. There is a [[neonatal intensive care unit]] at the hospital. In addition, there are multiple different wards, such as [[dentistry|dental]] and [[breast cancer]] wards, to treat mothers' various health problems.
The hospital employs a unique system of [[Videotelephony|video call]] booths for family to communicate with a woman who has given birth, as family members are restricted from being in personal contact with the newborn and the mother for five days. It is believed that this helps to prevent infections.
[[Traditional Korean medicine]] is used conspicuously in the treatment of patients, and around 30 percent of all given treatments are based on traditional methods.
In 2012 the hospital was expanded when a new wing specialized for breast cancer was constructed at the hospital grounds by orders of [[Kim Jong-un]].
==History== In the 1970s, a state policy for maternity issues was initiated.<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005"/> [[Kim Jong-il]] decided to build the hospital in 1978, and it was rumored that he wished that no women would die any longer due to pregnancy complications, as his mother [[Kim Jong-suk]] had died.<ref name="Lim2008">{{cite book|author=Jae-Cheon Lim|title=Kim Jong-il's Leadership of North Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ag16AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA22|date=24 November 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-01712-6|page=22}}</ref> The achievement of building the hospital was used as means to emphasize Kim Jong-il's achievements for his confirmed status as a [[List of leaders of North Korea|heir apparent]].<ref name="NKLW_2012_Oct"/>
The Pyongyang Maternity Hospital was part of the [[Pyongyang Speed campaign]] to construct various public facilities for the [[6th Congress of the Workers' Party of Korea]], which took place on 10–14 October 1980—the congress' beginning coincided with the 35th [[Party Foundation Day]]<ref>{{cite book|author=|title=Kim Jong Il – Brief History|date=1998|url=http://www.korea-dpr.info/lib/103.pdf|publisher=[[Foreign Language Publishing House]]|page=79|access-date=27 March 2016}}</ref>—and the congress was followed by large construction projects continuing into the early 1980s. The hospital was completed in less than nine months.<ref name="Willoughby2014">{{cite book|author=Robert Willoughby|title=North Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z4XKBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA115|date=22 July 2014|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-476-1|page=115}}</ref><ref name="Sechiyama2013">{{cite book|author=Kaku Sechiyama|title=Patriarchy in East Asia: A Comparative Sociology of Gender|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wN5X31LS6hwC&pg=PA215|date=1 March 2013|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-23060-2|page=215}}</ref><ref name="Hunter1999">{{cite book|author=Helen-Louise Hunter|title=Kim Il-song's North Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lrz5OJvCkmIC&pg=PA125|date=1 January 1999|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-96296-8|page=125}}</ref> Completed in 1979, the hospital began operating on the 34th anniversary of the [[Law on Sex Equality]] on 30 July 1980.<ref name="Lim2008"/><ref name="Corfield2014">{{cite book|author=Justin Corfield|title=Historical Dictionary of Pyongyang|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5zKWBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA178|date=1 December 2014|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=978-1-78308-341-1|pages=xxi, 59–60, 160–161, 177–179, 205}}</ref><ref name="Pictorial_Korea_2015">{{cite news |author=Kang Su Jong |date=July 2015 |title=Pyongyang Maternity Hospital with 35-Year History |url=http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/periodic/korea/index.php?contents+4600+2015-07+303+2 |newspaper=[[Korea Pictorial]] |location=[[Pyongyang]] |publisher= |issn=1727-9208 |access-date=28 November 2015}}</ref> The hospital was praised as one of the best in mainland Northeast Asia after opening; the quality of maternity care in the country had improved since the 1940s and 1950s.<ref name="O'Reilly2010">{{cite book|author=Andrea O'Reilly|title=Encyclopedia of Motherhood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UP9yAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA622|date=6 April 2010|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4522-6629-9|page=622}}</ref>
Around 2005, nationwide attention was given to maternity hospitals and [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|obstetric and gynecological]] departments to ensure that a larger proportion of women would receive in-hospital care for childbirth by competent medical staff. The Pyongyang Maternity Hospital's management and facilities were also improved at that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/cedaw33/responses/kor/kor-E.pdf|title=Written replies by the Democratic People's Republic of Korea concerning the list of issues and questions (CEDAW/PSWG/2005/II/CRP.1/Add.3) issued by the Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women|date=March 2005|website=[[United Nations]]|pages=14–15|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref>
In 2012 the hospital was expanded by [[Kim Jong-un]] with a new wing, equipped with modern medical equipment, which houses the Breast Cancer Research Center.<ref name="RT_2012">{{cite web |url=https://www.rt.com/op-edge/north-korea-reforms-isolation-119/|title=North Korea’s Socialist Winter: Engagement or isolation? (Photo Perspectives) |last=Bowie |first=Nile |date=16 December 2012 |website=[[RT (TV network)|RT]] |publisher= |access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref><ref name="Huffington_2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/24/north-korea-health-care_n_3491380.html |title=North Korea Health Care: Freezing Hospitals Cast Doubt On Official Narrative |last=Mason |first=Margie |date=24 June 2013 |website=[[Huffington Post]] |publisher= |access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref> The hospital has a personal connection for Kim Jong-un, as it had for his father Kim Jong-il, as Kim Jong-un's mother [[Ko Yong-hui]] died due to breast cancer.<ref name="NKLW_2012_Oct">{{cite web|url=https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/2012/10/09/dprk-premier-opens-mammography-center-in-pyongyang/|title=DPRK Premier Opens Mammography Center in Pyongyang|website=[[North Korea Leadership Watch]]|date=9 October 2012|access-date=27 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005846/https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/2012/10/09/dprk-premier-opens-mammography-center-in-pyongyang/|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Facilities== [[File:North Korea-Pyongyang Maternity Hospital-04.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|alt=|Dental ward for the patients.]]
Health services are provided for childbirth, infertility, menstrual disorder, dystonia, chronic inflammatory disease, problems associated with pregnancy and cardiology, neurology, ophthalmology, dentistry, ear, nose and throat, and physiotherapy.<ref name="WHO_2005"/> In addition, a [[neonatal intensive care unit]] operates at the hospital.<ref name="UCSF_2006"/>
The hospital has 1,500 beds, which include 650 beds for [[obstetrics]] patients, 350 for [[gynecology]] patients, 57 for [[general medicine|general medical]] care, and 500 for children.<ref name="WHO_2005"/> Floor space of the hospital is 60,000 m<sup>2</sup> on 13 floors and 2,030 rooms.<ref name="Corfield2014"/> There is also a library with 100,000 volumes.<ref name="Corfield2014"/>
The hospital trains North Korean nurses and midwives for work outside of Pyongyang.<ref name="Corfield2014"/> North Korean sources claim that women's health care services can be provided via [[telemedicine]] to hospitals and clinics outside Pyongyang.<ref name="NKLW_2012">{{cite web|url=https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/2012/11/04/kim-jong-un-visits-breast-cancer-research-center-health-complex-ice-rink-and-skate-park/|title=Kim Jong Un Visits Breast Cancer Research Center, Health Complex, Ice Rink and Skate Park|website=[[North Korea Leadership Watch]]|date=4 November 2012|access-date=26 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304194553/https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/2012/11/04/kim-jong-un-visits-breast-cancer-research-center-health-complex-ice-rink-and-skate-park/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Korea_Today_2013"/>
===Breast Cancer Research Center===
Kim Jong-un gave orders to build a new wing for the hospital in 2012. The Breast Cancer Research Center, also known as the Breast Cancer Institute, began operating in this wing on 8 October 2012.<ref name="NKLW_2012_Oct"/> The institute has a floor space of 8,500 m<sup>2</sup> on six floors and over 160 rooms. It contains rooms for [[CT scan]] and [[X-ray]], and other rooms for medical procedures such as treating tumours. Achieving early diagnosis and regular [[cancer screening]] were goals set for the new medical services offered by the institute. There is also office space for research work.<ref name="Pictorial_Korea_2015"/><ref name="RT_2012"/><ref name="Huffington_2013"/><ref name="Korea_Today_2013"/>
===Traditional medicine=== {{further|Traditional Korean medicine}}
Pyongyang Maternity Hospital uses both conventional and traditional medicine to treat patients.<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005"/> The hospital has a Department of Traditional Medicine known as '''The Koryo Medical Gynecology Department'''. Traditional medicine is used for treating obstetrics and gynecology patients. A separate pharmacy for [[Herbalism|herbal medicine]] exists, and there are facilities for producing traditional medicines within the hospital. A manufacturing unit for herbal medicines maintains extraction, sterilization, and storage units within the hospital.<ref name="WHO_2005">{{cite web |url=http://apps.searo.who.int/PDS_DOCS/B0020.pdf |title=Development of Traditional Medicine in the South-East Asia Region |author= |date=November 2005 |website=[[WHO]] |pages=26–27 |access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref>
Around 60 different traditional medicines were in use {{As of|2005|lc=y}}. Common traditional treatments include [[cupping therapy]], [[moxibustion]], and [[acupuncture]] with and without [[Electroacupuncture|electric charge]]. Approximately 30 percent of services provided by the hospital are based on traditional medicine.<ref name="WHO_2005"/>
==Equipment and staff== [[File:North Korea - Doctor (5609468151).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|alt=|A doctor working in an office.]]
[[Kim Song-hui (director)|Kim Song-hui]] is the director of the Pyongyang Maternity Hospital, and {{as of|2015|7|23|lc=y}} the vice-director of the hospital is Han Myong-gun.<ref name="UNICEF_2009"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2015/201507/news23/20150723-21ee.html|archive-url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2015/201507/news23/20150723-21ee.html|title=Sci-Tech Disseminating Room in Pyongyang Maternity Hospital|website=[[KCNA]]|date=23 July 2015|archive-date=31 January 2016|access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref> {{As of|1989}} 70-percent of the staff was female.<ref name="Chung">{{cite book|author=Donald K. Chung|title=The Three Day Promise: A Korean Soldier’s Memoir|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zR4aD6rpUPwC&pg=PT245|publisher=Pacifica Military History|date=1989|isbn=978-1-890988-51-7|page=245}}</ref>
The hospital contains a unique system of visitor booths, which can be accessed directly from the ground floor,<ref name="RobinsonBartlett2007"/> to be used by fathers and other family members.<ref name="WHO_2005"/><ref name="Corfield2014"/> This system of [[Closed-circuit television|closed circuit cameras]] and televisions is used for [[Videotelephony|video calls]].<ref name="WHO_2005"/><ref name="Corfield2014"/><ref name="O'Reilly2010"/> They are meant to protect newborn babies and mothers from infection.<ref name="WHO_2005"/><ref name="O'Reilly2010"/><ref name="Lafforgue_2008"/> Fathers and other visitors may not be in contact with mothers and babies for the first five days after birth,<ref name="RobinsonBartlett2007">{{cite book|author1=Martin Robinson|author2=Ray Bartlett|author3=Rob Whyte|title=Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vX4uMBxzml8C&pg=PA366|year=2007|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74104-558-1|page=366}}</ref> and in the meantime use these booths.<ref name="WHO_2005"/><ref name="Lafforgue_2008">{{cite web |url=http://www.flickriver.com/photos/mytripsmypics/2878824352/ |title=Maternity hospital: You are a father! Pyongyang North Korea |last=Lafforgue |first=Eric |website=www.flickriver.com |date=8 September 2008 |access-date=26 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20160331215802/http://www.flickriver.com/photos/mytripsmypics/2878824352/ |archivedate=31 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Breast Cancer Research Center was featured on the local news in 2012 after it had received two advanced [[Siemens Healthcare|Siemens]] [[Medical imaging|medical imaging scanners]]. [[North Korea Tech]] speculated from the news that these were Artis and Somatom Emotion type medical scanners. However, modern medical equipment remains rare in the North Korean healthcare system,<ref name="NorthKoreaTech_2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.northkoreatech.org/tag/pyongyang-maternity-hospital/ |title=Pyongyang Maternity Hospital gets advanced Siemens scanners |last=Williams |first=Martyn |date=28 September 2012 |website=[[North Korea Tech]] |publisher= |access-date=29 November 2015}}</ref> despite the presence of some advanced equipment from Siemens.<ref name="Business_Insider_2014"/> {{As of|February 2009}} old equipment dating back from the 1970s was still in use.<ref name="Business_Insider_2014">{{citeweb|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/north-korean-healthcare-2014-5|title=I Had A Scary Encounter With North Korea’s Crumbling Healthcare System|last=Mack|first=Benjamin|website=[[Business Insider]]|date=1 June 2014|access-date=3 April 2016}}</ref>
Members of the NGO ''WomenCrossDMZ'' were told on their visit to the hospital that international sanctions had previously stopped the hospital from obtaining necessary parts for an x-ray machine. Experts have responded unclearly on these claims that the sanctions could cause problems with medicine. However, the x-ray machine contains radioactive materials, which complicates the export of such machines from the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nknews.org/2015/05/koreas-peace-symposium-pushes-for-more-engagement/ |title=Koreas’ Peace Symposium pushes for more engagement |last=Leo |first=Leo |website=[[NK News]] |date=26 May 2015 |access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref>
==Patients and visitors== [[File:North Korea-Pyongyang Maternity Hospital-06.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|alt=|Visitor booths for fathers and other family members.]] {{As of|2014}} the daily amount of new patients is 400, and it has been estimated that 710,000 children have been born at the hospital.<ref name="Corfield2014"/> In 2006 around 30 babies were born daily.<ref name="UCSF_2006">{{cite web|url=https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2006/10/7108/ucsf-doctor-explores-north-korea|title=UCSF Doctor Explores North Korea|last=Miller|first=Jeff|website=[[University of California, San Francisco]]|date=26 October 2006|access-date=27 March 2016}}</ref> {{As of|2015|6|17}}, 453 triplets have been born in the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|archive-url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2015/201506/news17/20150617-20ee.html|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2015/201506/news17/20150617-20ee.html|title=Triplets Born in Pyongyang Maternity Hospital|website=[[KCNA]]|date=17 June 2015|archive-date=26 February 2016|access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref> The first triplets were born in September 1980.<ref name="Lafforgue_2008"/>
All mothers from Pyongyang are admitted to the hospital for their first birth.<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005"/><ref name="RobinsonBartlett2007"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/a-13-2005-11-03-voa10-66906252/377058.html|title=North Korea's Upper Class Flourishes in Sharp Contrast to Reports of Impoverished Working Class|website=[[Voice of America]]|date=28 October 2009|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> Any North Korean woman may come to give birth to her first baby in the hospital.<ref name="Independent_2012">{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/journey-into-the-heart-of-north-korea-7640702.html |title=Journey into the heart of North Korea |last=Newson |first=Tomiko |date=13 April 2012 |website=[[The Independent]] |publisher= |access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2005-10-30/news/0510300001_1_north-korea-kim-il-sung-demilitarized/2|title=Reality, fiction hard to discern in N. Korea|website=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|page=2|date=30 October 2005|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> Mothers typically stay for ten days after giving birth, and those who give birth through a [[Caesarean section]] stay for 15 days. Mothers of triplets are hospitalized until the smallest child weights at least {{convert|6|kg}}.<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005"/> However, Chinese media claims that access to the hospital requires a correct background (''[[Songbun]]'') or a connection with an employee of the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.donga.com/List/3/all/26/409657/1|title=Chinese media: Pyongyang is exclusively for the privileged|website=[[The Dong-a Ilbo]]|date=9 December 2014|access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref> In addition, the inability of common people to conveniently travel from city to city adds another barrier to access to hospitals with high-quality treatments.<ref name="HassigOh2015">{{cite book|author1=Ralph Hassig|author2=Kongdan Oh|title=The Hidden People of North Korea: Everyday Life in the Hermit Kingdom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7T19CAAAQBAJ&pg=PA86|date=16 April 2015|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4422-3719-3|page=86}}</ref>
Mothers who have given birth to triplets and quadruplets are given gifts. Silver knives are given for boys, and gold rings are given for girls.<ref name="Corfield2014"/> Clothes and blankets have been also given as gifts.<ref name="Lafforgue_2008"/> The children born from a [[multiple birth]] of three or more are taken from their parents until they are four years old.<ref name="Independent_2012"/>
Leader Kim Jong-un has visited and given field guidance at the hospital multiple times. [[Premier of North Korea|Premiers]] [[Kim Yong-nam]] and [[Choe Yong Rim]] have also visited.<ref name="NKLW_2012"/><ref name="Korea_Today_2013">{{cite news |author1=Rim Sang-jun |author2=Ri Song-ik |title=To Protect and Promote Women’s Health |url= |newspaper=[[Korea Today]] |number=680 |publisher=[[The Foreign Language Magazines]] |location=Pyongyang |date=February 2013 |pages=30–31 |issn=0454-4072 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201207/news01/20120701-26ee.html|title=Kim Jong Un Provides Field Guidance to Rungna People's Pleasure Ground and Breast Cancer Institute|website=[[KCNA]]|date=1 July 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012083741/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201207/news01/20120701-26ee.html|archive-date=12 October 2014|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> For instance, premier Choe Yong Rim and other party officials attended the opening ceremony of the Breast Cancer Research Center's new wing on 8 October 2012.<ref name="NKLW_2012_Oct"/> He made another field inspection on 30 December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/2012/12/30/dprk-premier-visits-pyongyang-maternity-hospital/|title=DPRK Premier Visits Pyongyang Maternity Hospital|website=[[North Korea Leadership Watch]]|date=30 December 2012|access-date=28 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305010403/https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/2012/12/30/dprk-premier-visits-pyongyang-maternity-hospital/|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Foreign patients and visitors=== Foreigners have been treated at the hospital, and many foreign children have been born here, including South Korean, Palestinian, and Cuban children.<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005"/><ref name="Pictorial_Korea_2015"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uriminzokkiri.com/index.php?ptype=english&no=11577|title=Foreign People Enjoying Good Fortune in Korea (1)|website=[[Uriminzokkiri]]|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> The first known South Korean baby to be born in North Korea was born on 10 October 2005 to a mother who had come to watch the [[Arirang Mass Games]].<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005"/> The baby was born on the 60th [[Party Foundation Day]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/nov/20/world/fg-baby20|title='Unification Baby' Seen as Omen by N. Koreans|last=Demick|first=Barbara|author-link=Barbara Demick|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|pages=1–2|date=20 November 2005|access-date=27 March 2016}}</ref> [[Tourism in North Korea|Foreign tourist groups]] are sometimes allowed to access the hospital.<ref name="PlanetRichmond2010">{{cite book|author1=Simon Richmond|author2=Yu-Mei Balasingamchow|author3=César G Soriano|author4=Rob Whyte|title=Lonely Planet Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h9-DOFiUI5oC&pg=PA369|date=1 September 2010|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74220-356-0|page=369}}</ref>
[[Lee Hui-ho]], the former [[First Spouse of South Korea]], visited on 5 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.khan.co.kr/khan_art_view.html?artid=201508061849497&code=710100|title=Lee Hee-ho Arrives in Pyongyang: Expectations of a Breakthrough in Inter-Korean Relations|author1=By Bak Eun-gyeong|author2=Jeong Hwan-bo|website=[[The Kyunghyang Shinmun]]|date=6 August 2015|access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2015/07/06/Widow-of-SKorea-President-Kim-Dae-jung-confirmed-to-visit-Pyongyang/8571436234567/|title=Widow of SKorea President Kim Dae-jung confirmed to visit Pyongyang|last=Shim|first=Elizabeth|website=[[UPI]]|date=6 July 2015|access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref> Some members of the [[Namibia]]n delegation led by [[President of Namibia|president]] [[Sam Nujoma]] visited the hospital in November 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/bitstream/handle/1808/10702/Kirkwood_ku_0099M_11463_DATA_1.pdf?sequence=1|title=Postcolonial Architecture Through North Korean Modes: Namibian Commissions of the Mansudae Overseas Project|author=Meghan Laurel Elizabeth Kirkwood|website=[[University of Kansas]]|date=January 2011|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref>
==Portrayals in North Korean culture== {{see also|Culture of North Korea}} {{external media | float = right | width = | image1 = [http://www.flickriver.com/photos/mytripsmypics/2878824352/ An inside of the camera booth in use.] | image2 = [https://c2.staticflickr.com/4/3441/3976683809_563d0b80c4_b.jpg Plaque of Baby-Friendly Hospital at the hospital grounds] }}
''[[Our Warm House]]'', a North Korean [[medical drama]] [[List of North Korean television series|television series]] filmed in 2000, was set in Pyongyang Maternity Hospital.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ri|first=Ok Gyong|editor1=Hong Chan Su |editor2=Ri Un Gyong |title=Korean film: Feature Film, TV Drama, Documentary, Science Film, Children's Film / |script-title=ko:조선 영화: 예술, 텔레비죤극, 기록, 과학, 아동 |language=English, Korean |others=Translated by Ro Yong Chol, Jang Hyang Gi and Yang Sung Mi |location=[[Pyongyang]] |publisher=[[Korea Film Export & Import Corporation]] |publication-date=15 September 2012|oclc=857899124 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="korf_Koreo">{{Cite web | title = Korea Film Coporation [sic]. Others. | publisher = Korea Film Corporation| work = korfilm.com.kp | accessdate = 25 November 2015 | url = http://www.korfilm.com.kp/index.php?language=eng|page=1}}</ref>
The hospital has commonly appeared in [[Korean Central News Agency]] (KCNA) news articles. Many of these news stories are about cases of triplets, and North Koreans are fascinated by triple births. When asked to explain this fascination, the doctors of the hospital explained that the third baby needs extra care as women only have two breasts for two children. As a result, the government provides help for mothers of triplets.<ref name="Joongang_Daily_2005">{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2639128|title=Activist mother lauds hospital care in North|author=Ser Myo-ja|website=[[Korea Joongang Daily]]|date=6 November 2005|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref>
==Awards== Pyongyang Maternity Hospital and [[North Pyongan Provincial Maternity Hospital]] were awarded plaques declaring them a ''Baby-Friendly Hospital'' on 5 February 2009 by the [[UNICEF]] [[UNICEF East Asia and Pacific Regional Office|Thailand office]] for attaining all ten targets of [[breastfeeding]] set by [[WHO]] and [[UNICEF]]. A reassessment in late 2008 indicated that the hospitals had met the targets. However, [[South Pyongan Provincial Maternity Hospital]], a new candidate for the award, did not meet the breastfeeding standards. Previously the Pyongyang Maternity Hospital and North Pyongan Provincial Maternity Hospital had been awarded in 1996. Director Kim Song-hui stated that in addition to health workers, both community-based and nursery workers will help mothers maintain breastfeeding after their hospital discharge. It was planned that by the end of 2009, there would be seven baby-friendly hospitals in North Korea.<ref name="UNICEF_2009">{{cite web |url=http://www.unicef.org/dprk/6620_10229.html |title=Baby-Friendly Hospital Award Ceremony |last=Sahin |first=Nilgun |date=5 February 2009 |website=[[UNICEF]] |publisher= |access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox writer | name = Raymond Durgnat | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1932|9|1}} | birth_place = London, England | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2002|5|19|1932|9|1}} | death_place = London, England<ref name="guardian" /> | occupation = Film critic | nationality = British | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Pembroke College, Cambridge]], [[Slade School of Fine Art]] | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = [[Thorold Dickinson]] | influenced = | awards = | signature = | website = | portaldisp = }}
'''Raymond Durgnat''' (1 September 1932 – 19 May 2002) was a British film critic, who was born in London of Swiss parents. During his life he wrote for virtually every major English language film publication. In 1965 he published the first major critical essay on [[Michael Powell]], who had hitherto been "fashionably dismissed by critics as a 'technician’s director'", as Durgnat put it.
His many books include ''Films and Feelings'' (1967), ''A Mirror for England: British Movies from Austerity to Affluence'' (1970), and ''The Strange Case of [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'' (1974). He wrote principally for ''[[Films and Filming]]'' (in the 1960s), ''[[Film Comment]]'' (in the 1970s) and ''[[Monthly Film Bulletin]]'' (in the 1980s), and taught at various art schools and universities, notably [[St Martin's College]] and the [[Royal College of Art]], where his students included [[Tony Scott]]. Toward the end of his life he was visiting professor at the [[University of East London]].<ref name="UEL HSS">,{{cite web|url= http://www.uel.ac.uk/hss/|title= UEL HSS|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091001100857/http://www.uel.ac.uk/hss/|archivedate= 1 October 2009|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
==Biography==
Durgnat was born in London in 1932 to Swiss parents who had emigrated to England in 1924.<ref name="guardian">[http://www.powell-pressburger.org/Obits/Durgnat/Guardian.html Raymond Durgnat: Prolific film critic contemptuous of his trade's doctrinal theories.]</ref> Durgnat's family was of [[French Huguenot]] descent, and he was raised in a religious [[Calvinism|Calvinist]] household.<ref name="rouge">[http://www.rouge.com.au/8/interview.html "Culture Always is a Fog:" Interview with Raymond Durgnat.] ''Rouge.''</ref> Durgnat's father worked as a [[window dresser]] but lost his job in 1932; afterwards, he opened a drapery shop.<ref name="rouge"/>
He was educated at the [[Sir George Monoux College|Sir George Monoux School]], a state grammar school in Walthamstow, before serving his statutory two years of [[Conscription in the United Kingdom#After 1945|National Service]], which he spent in the [[Royal Army Educational Corps|Education Corps]] in Hong Kong,<ref name="rouge"/> then a British possession. After leaving the army in 1954, he studied English Literature at [[Pembroke College, Cambridge]].<ref name="guardian"/> With the filmmaker [[Don Levy]], Durgnat became one of the first post-graduate students of film in Britain, studying under [[Thorold Dickinson]] (director of ''[[Gaslight (1940 film)|Gaslight]]'' and ''[[The Next of Kin]]'') at the [[Slade School of Fine Art]] from 1960. The thesis he wrote there provided the source material for a number of his books.
In the early 1950s, he had written for ''[[Sight and Sound]]'', but fell out with this [[British Film Institute]] publication after the exit of [[Gavin Lambert]] in 1957, often accusing it of elitism, puritanism, and upper-middle-class snobbery, notably in his 1963 essay "Standing Up For Jesus" (which appeared in the short-lived magazine ''Motion'', which he co-edited with Ian Johnson) and in his 1965 piece "Auteurs and Dream Factories" (an edited version of which later appeared in ''Films and Feelings''). From 1960 he was a regular presence in the monthly [https://www.academia.edu/3284715/The_Queer_History_of_Films_and_Filming ''Films and Filming''], writing reviews and serial essays.
In 1966–7 he was a major player in the nascent [[London Film-Makers' Co-op]] (LFMC),<ref>Kevin Gough-Yates [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/may/24/guardianobituaries1 Obituary: Raymond Durgnat], ''The Guardian'', 24 May 2002</ref> then based at [[Better Books]] on Charing Cross Road, a hub of the emerging British [[Underground (British subculture)|underground]]. As the LFMC's chairman he was instrumental in promoting filmmakers such as [http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/1359564/index.html Jeff Keen] and [[Stephen Dwoskin]], writing the first articles on both.
The rise of structural film (at the LFMC) and of structuralism (in the journal [[Screen (journal)|''Screen'']]) – and the far-left politics which accompanied the latter – saw Durgnat become an outsider figure within British film culture. In 1973 he moved to Canada, beginning a peripatetic teaching career in North America which took him to New York, San Francisco, and Los Angeles. In the late 1970s he taught film at the [[University of California, San Diego]] alongside [[Manny Farber]], [[Jean-Pierre Gorin]] and [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]].<ref name="RosenbaumonFarber">Rosenbaum, Jonathan. [http://www.jonathanrosenbaum.net/?p=14534 They Drive by Night: The Criticism of Manny Farber.]</ref>
Returning to London at the close of the decade, he launched a series of withering assaults on the linguistics-based film theory that had come to dominate film academia over the previous decade; perhaps as a result, he did not published another new book until 1999. He did, however, return to write for the BFI publication ''[[Monthly Film Bulletin]]'' in the years before its merger with ''Sight and Sound'' in 1991, and contributed to that publication again later in the 1990s.
His last two books, including ''A Long Hard look at Psycho'', were also published by the BFI. ''The Essential Raymond Durgnat'', published in 2014 – again by the BFI – contains previously unpublished work, including a translation of an essay originally published in [[Positif (magazine)|''Positif'']] on Michael Powell, on whom Durgnat began but did not complete a full-length book. It also includes such rare pieces as "Standing Up for Jesus". The collection was described by [[Adrian Martin]] as "[http://www.filmkrant.nl/world_wide_angle/11499 the essential film book of this or almost any year]".
Durgnat's socio-political approach – strongly supportive of the working classes and, almost as a direct result of this, American popular culture, and dismissive of left-wing intellectuals whom he accused of actually being [[Petite bourgeoisie|petit-bourgeois]] conservatives in disguise, and dismissive of overt politicisation of film criticism, refusing to bring his own left-wing views overtly into his writings on film – can best be described as "radical populist".
==Bibliography== *''Nouvelle Vague: The First Decade'' A Motion Monograph, London, 1963, 102 pages *''[[Greta Garbo]]'' Studio Vista/Dutton Pictureback, New York, 1965, reprinted 1967, 1970, 160 pages *''Eros in the Cinema'' Calder and Boyars, London, 1966, 207 pages *''Films and Feelings'' The MIT Press, Cambridge; Faber and Faber, London 1967, 288 pages *''[[Georges Franju|Franju]]'' University of California Press, Berkeley, 1968, 144 pages *''[[Luis Buñuel]]'' University of California Press, Berkeley, 1968, 152 pages *''Children of Albion: Poetry of the "Underground" in Britain'' (poem: "Scrap Iron"), Penguin, Baltimore, 1969, 384 pages *''[[Samuel Fuller]]'' (essay "China Gate") Edinburgh Film Festival, Edinburgh, 1969, 128 pages *''The Films of [[Robert Bresson]]'' Praeger, New York, 1969, 144 pages *''The Crazy Mirror: Hollywood Comedy and the American Image'' Horizon Press, New York, 1970, 280 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-8180-0701-9}} *''A Mirror for England: British Movies From Austerity to Affluence'' Faber and Faber, London 1970, 394 pages, {{ISBN|978-1-84457-453-7}} *''Sexual Alienation in the Cinema: the dynamics of sexual freedom'' Studio Vista, London, 1972, 320 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-289-70261-1}} *''The Strange Case of [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'' The MIT Press, Cambridge; Faber and Faber, London 1974, 419 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-262-04041-9}} / {{ISBN|978-0-571-09966-5}} *''[[Jean Renoir]]'' The University of California Press, Berkeley, 1974, 429 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-520-02283-6}} *''Durgnat on Film'' Faber and Faber, London, 1976, 238 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-571-10656-1}} *''[[Luis Buñuel]]'' University of California Press, Berkeley, 1977, 176 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-520-03424-2}} *''[[Michael Powell]], [[Emeric Pressburger|Pressburger]] and Others'' BFI Publishing, London, 1978, 124 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-85170-086-1}} (Essay in collection) *''[[King Vidor]], American'' The University of California Press, Berkeley, 1988, 382 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-520-05798-2}} *''[[Michael Powell]] and English Genius'' Taylor & Francis Group, London, 1992, {{ISBN|978-0-415-03373-2}} *''[[WR: Mysteries of the Organism]]'' BFI Publishing, distributed by The University of California Press, Berkeley, 1999, 96 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-85170-720-4}} *''A Long Hard Look at "Psycho"'' BFI Publishing, distributed by The University of California Press, Berkeley, 2002, 248 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-85170-920-8}} *''The Essential Raymond Durgnat'' Palgrave Macmillan/BFI, 2014, 256 pages, {{ISBN|978-1-84457-451-3}}

'''[[Rehabilitation engineering|Rehabilitation Engineering]] and [[Assistive technology|Assistive Technology]] Society of North America''' ('''RESNA''') is an association of people with an interest in [[technology]] and [[disability]]. Its [[mission statement]] notes that RESNA's mission is to improve the potential of people with disabilities to achieve their goals through the use of technology through promoting research, development, education, advocacy and provision of technology; and by supporting the [[assistive technology service provider]]s engaged in these activities.
RESNA was started in August 1979. In 1993 RESNA became a self-managed organization. RESNA has over 1,000 members, the bulk of whom are concentrated in the US and Canada.
Beginning in 1995, RESNA developed certification programs for credentialing professionals working as assistive technology service providers.<ref>Lenker, J.A., "Certification in Assistive Technology", ''OT Practice'' 5(21), 2000. reproduced at http://www.wheelchairnet.org/WCN_ProdServ/Clinicians/ATPCertification.html</ref><ref>"Stakeholders Applaud RESNA Move to Combine ATS/ATP Certifications", ''HomeCare Magazine'', Sept. 8, 2008, {{cite web |url=http://homecaremag.com/mobility/wheelchairs/stakeholders-applaud-resna-move/index1.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712214537/http://homecaremag.com/mobility/wheelchairs/stakeholders-applaud-resna-move/index1.html |archivedate=2011-07-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>"Resna sets score for Exam", ''HomeCare Magazine'', Oct. 22, 2010, http://homecaremag.com/mobility/seating-postioning-resna-certification-20100202/</ref><ref>"RESNA expands Certification in Seating and Positioning, ''HME News'', Feb. 2, 2010, http://www.hmenews.com/?p=article&id=hm201010MmsV1K</ref> These certification programs are administered through RESNA's Professional Standards Board (PSB), which includes representatives from RESNA, the National Registry of Rehabilitation Technology Suppliers (NRRTS), and consumers. In December 2015, the Rehabilitation Engineering Assistive Technology Society of North America (RESNA) updated the WC18 standards for wheelchair tie-down and occupant restraint systems (WTORS)standards for wheelchair tie-down and occupant restraint systems (WTORS).<ref>"WC18 at a Glance, http://sure-lok.com/wc18-at-a-glance-2/</ref> RESNA is governed by a 14-member Board of Directors. The president is Roger O. Smith, PhD, OT, FAOTA, RESNA Fellow
== Sister organizations == * [http://www.aaate.net Association for the Advancement of Assistive Technology in Europe (AAATE)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070618140938/http://www.e-bility.com/arata/ Australian Rehabilitation and Assistive Technology Association (ARATA)] * [http://www.resja.gr.jp/eng/index.html Rehabilitation Engineering Society of Japan (RESJA)] * [http://www.supera.org.pt Portuguese Society of Rehabilitation Engineering and Accessibility (SUPERA)]
